Casinos function as a tax on the people least able to pay more taxes. If governments need more money, they should raise taxes on people who can pay them. Casinos kill neighbourhoods. No one wants to go near them unless they're going to gamble. Other businesses die or fail to start. Quite apart from sucking money from people and communities, casinos are a major planning problem. Casinos are not built to be an inclusive part of a community, but as an island. In so doing they brand that region into an area not suitable for other businesses, homes or parks. They create a vacuum. Casinos do not contribute to a community, they take away. The sums they promise to deliver to city coffers are about as reliable as the return on investment of a stack of poker chips. Casinos are built in cities and townships in decline, where no other source of income is viable. Toronto is a vibrant , growing community with vast and realized potentials. We are not Windsor, Niagara or Detroit.

I believe that gambling is a public health issue as the harms of problem gambling to individuals and the costs to society are enormous. There is peer-reviewed, Ontario-based scientific evidence that informs this concern. According In Ontario, about 3% experiences problem gambling. Problem gambling is associated with mental health issues such as depression, anxiety, and suicide; it also affects family and marital relationships, work and academic performance, and can lead to bankruptcy and crime. Suicide is a critical concern. A recent study found that a quarter of Ontario student problems with gambling problems reported a suicide attempt in the past year  roughly 18 times higher than in the general student population (Cook et al., 2010). The risk of suicide is also high among older adults with gambling problems (Nower & Blaszcynski, 2008). Research shows that increases in gambling availability including location and extended hours of operation are associated with increases in problem gambling. There is international evidence that the number of people presenting for problem gambling treatment and the number of bankruptcies both rise following the opening of casinos (Williams, Rehm, and Stevens, 2011). Any legislation enacted by the City of Toronto, such as gambling policy, should privileges public health over revenues to mitigate the harms associated with problem gambling.

Jobs and revenue that casinos bring do not outweigh the social costs imposed.  Besides fueling/supporting/profiting from addiction, casinos are a sad last resort for cities to generate revenue while genuine revenue streams are privatized (like garbage collection). Casino as cultural venue does not function to build community, but relies on creating consumer spectacle in place of genuine cultural production, which relies on socially cohesive activity.  How much people spend on entertainment is not unlimited.  Casino popularity is driven, in part, by spectacle: how many of the surrounding, independent venues will not be able to compete with a multinational's ability to out-spectacle legitimate culturally productive businesses? While independent business will plough profits back into surrounding neighbourhoods, a multinational gambling consortium will maximize how much wealth is redirected out of our economy, into head offices located in offshore tax havens, etc.  Casinos ultimately drain wealth, prosperity from communities and leave debt, bankruptcy, domestic violence, drug and alcohol addiction, crime, and suicide behind.

Democracy. Torontonians do not want a casino. Although the Ontario government has removed the condition that a city referendum is required to approve a casino, it is clear that there is loud and widespread opposition to a casino in Toronto and that the consultation process has attempted to sideline this opposition. Even the OLG Chair has admitted he does not want a casino in his neighbourhood. Toronto is a city of neighbourhoods, and if residents do not want a casino in their neighbourhood, then there should not be a casino in their neighbourhood. Health and Social Impacts. There is clear evidence that casinos have costly health and social impacts, including problem gambling, financial difficulties, family breakdown, divorce, compromised child development, substance abuse, depression and even suicide. These negative impacts affect disadvantaged groups disproportionately, including youth, Aboriginal peoples and low-income families. A casino will do irreparable damage to Toronto's urban fabric, destroying local businesses, attractions and entertainment for a cheap thrill with dubious economic benefits.

It would increase the parking problem & congestion in toronto. Gamling is not the most efficient way to incerase revenue.  Much of the revenue the government gains from a new casino, would be offset by losses elsewhere in the economy. Moreover, there will be additional public costs arising from new infrastructure requirements, increased rates of gambling addiction and instances of crime  from criminal activity caused by problem gamblers supporting their addiction, to loan sharking and money laundering. Casinos do not necessarily attract tourists who would not otherwise have visited the area. Indeed, downtown Toronto is already a tourism magnet. Introducing a casino would likely lead tourists, as well as residents, to change their entertainment spending  such as choosing to gamble instead of going to a restaurant or to the theater  rather than enticing people to spend more money in the city.

Too many casino gamblers lose too much money for their own good, but this also moves money from established entertainment (live or movie theatres, concerts, dining, etc.) See my notes in Q6 about population centres. The Ernst & Young report's low estimate of hosting fee is $18 million, consistent with OLG's proposed sliding scale (the marginal rate drops to 0.5% of net revenue after the first $500million). The $168 is based on unsubstantiated "discussion" about a 50-50 partnership that is not explained anywhere, and not mentioned in OLG modernization site. And OLG estimates its property tax as "not applicable". Finally, they estimate 3,600 cars whether for a stand-alone casino or integrated complex with double the gaming tables and another 1,000 slots...how carefully was anything estimated? The discussion in Toronto has been framed as "Toronto or Mississauga or City of Vaughan". But OLG wants gaming in each zone, including Pickering (C3), Milton (C4) and Hamilton (SW7). And probably in Mississauga (C2). Lots of competition encircling the GTA. And why would "international high rollers" come to 1 casino in Toronto when there are over 2 dozen on the Las Vegas strip?

A casino is not congruent with positive community values or a vision for a truly liveable city. It promises social problems, gambling addictions, and increased crime. Economic development of the kind we are currently enjoying downtown (growth in residential and commercial developments) will be harmed by the presence of a casino. As Godfrey said, "No one wants to live next to a casino." No one wants to locate their office beside one either. Further, the casino will economically harm the businesses around it, as it is an inward facing business. More economic harm. We're being asked to say "yes" to a casino without concrete numbers for benefits, concrete funding and programs for mitigating social harm, and concrete funding and plans for mitigating the burden on transportation and physical infrastructure. We're being asked to change course for the vision of our waterfront, our downtown, and more generally for our city. In exchange, we're being asked to say "Yes" without concrete information. It's a 'just trust us' scenario, and those never work out.

Any new casino in Toronto would incur social costs (related to gambling addiction, alcohol abuse, etc) that all taxpayers ALSO pay for. These negative social costs do not outweigh (and really should not even be directly compared to) the potential net revenue that increasingly failing casinos around North America may generate. Casinos (especially large-scale showcase projects) suck the lifeblood from local, small- to medium, and even larger competing shopping mall businesses as well as pedestrian traffic in the area because the nature of a successful casino is to keep people inside the casino. These negative spin-off effects of a successful casino would depress the local economy and actually detract a wide spectrum of non-gambling visitors from coming to whatever community a casino may be located in. Again, in context, a casino does not meet the multiple concurrent objectives of the City of Toronto to generate long-term revenues and to create an innovative, sustainable, attractive city in the 21st century. Casinos are a passe idea that do not generate any where near the net revenues or jobs that proponents market to the City and the public - even without accounting for the social costs to taxpayers. If the Government of Ontario locates a casino in Toronto, this will necessarily significantly endanger any revenues other smaller municipalities with more simple local economies throughout the province currently receive. The net economic and social benefits to Toronto are marginal but other smaller municipalities rely heavily on the benefits of their (nearby) casinos. These competing objectives do not make sense other than the potential benefit from large campaign donations.

There is a connection between casinos, organized crime, money laundering, drugs and prostitution.  There are much healthier ways to spur economic development. Toronto has a global reputation as a great place to raise families.  If we allow casinos to compromise that image, we will suffer economically, as it will become more difficult to attract world-class talent to Bay Street, our most important driver of economic growth. With tens of thousands of new condo units being occupied every quarter of every year, the downtown core is becoming more congested, and the infrastructure is already being strained.  Opening a casino would place additional stress on the downtown core, and could compromise the ability to provide high-quality, reliable power, transportation, policing, fire, and other key infrastructure and service elements.

A casino doesn't generate revenue, it redistributes it.  I believe a casino in Toronto would have the impact of relatively impoverishing neighboring municipalities, which is not at all what I want for the city. Unlike other cultural attractions (AGO, ROM, TSO, etc.), casinos are self-contained destinations.  I believe there is no reasonable expectation of a casino benefiting the city more broadly (visitors spending on restaurants, shops, or parking in the neighborhood) aside from the net contribution to general revenues, to which I'm opposed (see 1 above). A casino has been proposed as a way of providing funding for the city's ongoing development, social programs, etc.  The same people who I expect to benefit from investments in these areas are the same people I expect will be frequenting the casino.  In other words, there is no net distributive effect - the city will continue to improve itself (which benefits everyone) on the backs of those who can least afford it.

There has been no evidence to show that a Casino will bring long lasting revenue to the City - the developers, yes - not the City.  The "Entertainment" area along Richmond and Adelaide in downtown Toronto is being consumed by residential and commercial activity, not tourist/recreation uses.  To have a Casino two blocks south of that area is not in keeping with the developing community. The jobs created are short-term during construction and then low paying, service jobs (food service, housekeeping, security guards, etc.), not high paying jobs that bring true growth to the city. There are no other large, lively, highly cultured, knowledge based cities around the world with a large casino in the downtown area - or even in the City itself.  New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas, Denver, San Fransisco, Vancouver, London, etc. do not have Casinos.  Las Vegas, Atlantic City are the two large areas in North America with Casinos, and they are not strong, vibrant communities for anyone other than tourists.  The Casino in Windsor was supposed to rejuvenate the city, and it did not.  The Casinos in Niagara Falls have brought back some of the tourist business, but there is nothing new or strong if you're not involved with the tourism industry.  There are no new knowledge or manufacturing based businesses.  The other Casinos across Ontario have not provided any very high paying jobs, and have not generated any larger and more sophisticated communities.  Rama, Sault Ste. Marie, Blue Heron, Thousand Islands, have only served to separate people from there money, and generate lots of low paying service jobs.  Investing in science or technology based businesses with the same amount of money will have a huge multiplyier effect not found with service businesses.

Will take business away from regions First Nations Reserves' funding The highly addictive nature of gamble plus easy access through public transit could cause those who cannot control their gambling limits to easily over spend and lead to additional problems. Its a cheap form of entertainment and would end up being a default entertainment option which would take business away from entertainment outlets that don't just 'entertain' but also educate in areas that build rich culture; history, art, music, dance, science, religion (ROM, Casa Loma, Science Center, National Ballet, Street Festivals, etc.). It will become a cheap and therefore default form of entertainment that will starve other business as a result.

The costs of gambling are far greater than the benefits. Studies show that for every dollar gambling produces for a local economy, three dollars are lost because of the economic and social costs of gambling. When government legalizes gambling, taxpayers lose - whether they gamble or not.  In a U.S. study, Professor John Kindt of the University of Illinois concluded that for every dollar of gambling revenue received by the state, taxpayers must put up a minimum of three dollars to cover expenses created by gambling. He found these costs include infrastructure expenditures, regulatory costs, expenses related to the criminal justice system and large social-welfare costs. (John Kindt, Statement before a hearing of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Small Business, September 21, 1994.) Gambling cannibalizes local businesses. A hundred dollars spent in a slot machine is a hundred dollars that is not spent in a local restaurant, theater or retail store. As Donald Trump told the Miami Herald, "People will spend a tremendous amount of money in casinos, money that they would normally spend on buying a refrigerator or a new car. Local businesses will suffer because they'll lose customer dollars to the casinos."  In a study conducted for the Ford Foundation, Robert Goodman refers to the "cannibalization" of non-gambling businesses, a term which he uses to describe the substantial decline in both jobs and revenues experienced by many nearby enterprises.  Money for gambling is usually diverted from people's discretionary expenditures. Not only are dollars diverted from other products and services, but governments often lose sales taxes which would have been spent on those products and services. (Goodman, Legalized Gambling, p. 51.) Gambling leads to addiction and crime.  Gambling addiction has become an epidemic among youth.  According to Dr. Howard Shaffer, Director of the Harvard Medical School Center for Addiction Studies, "Today, there are more children experiencing adverse symptoms from gambling than from drugs...and the problem is growing."  Also, the serious problems associated with compulsive gambling affect more than the gamblers and their families; society has to pay a staggering amount as a result of that irresponsible behavior. Henry Lesieur, who chairs the department of criminal justice at Illinois State University, has found that compulsive gamblers engage in an estimated $1.3 billion in insurance-related fraud each year. (Henry Lesieur, "Compulsive Gambling," Society, May/June 1992, p. 45.)

There are already many gambling facilities in and around Toronto.  A new casino will only aggravate social and health problems, particularly to those who are more exposed to risk of problem-gambling, i.e. low income people, male adults, young and relatively elderly people and people who have mental health issues or addictions.  Additionally there is no overall plan to cope with the potential increase of problem gambling, in terms of facilities, institutions, programs and trained personnel in counselling and medical treatment, and control in crime rates. A new casino will bring about many related issues - prostitution, loan sharks, extortion, and abuses that are all part of the problem and increase crime rate.   These issues are already evident in casinos in other parts of the world. The main incentives for a new casino are job creation and increase in revenue.  These will be negated with an increase in crime rate and health care expenses.

Increased availability and access to gambling is associated with increased rates of problem gambling. There are already a number of gambling activities which are readily available in the city. We do NOT need any more. Problem gambling is associated with a range of negative impacts on physical and mental health, including ill health, fatigue, co-related substance use and addiction, depression and suicide among others. These impacts occur alongside others such as financial difficulties, family breakdown, divorce and compromised child development. The impacts extend beyond the gamblers themselves, and affect the health and well-being of family, friends, colleagues and communities. While there are many interventions available for problem gambling, much remains unknown about how to treat problem gambling. Only a minority of problem gamblers (1-2% per year) seeks or receives treatment. Furthermore, there is limited evidence on the effectiveness of interventions to prevent problem gambling.

Impact on our downtown economy. Toronto made it through the last recession relatively unscathed. In fact, we built dozens of new downtown towers. Not just condos, but commercial towers too! All while development in cities across the world (especially Las Vegas) was at a standstill. If anything, a downtown casino will make our core more vulnerable to a recession. Also, Important to consider the 30,000+ people that have moved into the downtown core in the last six years. Casinos are not suitable for residentinal neighbourhoods, and Trintiy Spadina is the fastest growing neighbourhood in the city. No concrete revenue numbers! The expected revenue figure from a casino keeps falling! First Ford said $200m, then the Ernst and Young report (admittedly flawed) said upwards of $168m (Based on a 50/50 revenue sharing structure. Current sharing rate in Ontario is about 4/96!). Now the OLG, the ones that will be handing out the money, have told the city to expect even less! At the current average 4% casino revenue for municipalities, Toronto would get ~$15m. And dont forget about all the associated costs. An entertainment complex subsidized by gambling revenues will undercut and threaten our already thriving theatre scene. Our great theatre scene is the result of local entrepreneurship and and abundance of Canadian talent. An MGM, sands or ceasars would ruin this.

I think the benefits of having a casino in Toronto are overstated and the costs associated are understated.  It is a net loss for the city.  I think the revenue that is being discussed is mainly displacement revenue as various venues throughout Toronto that are well placed within the existing infrastructure suffer because the casino can undercut and outbid other organizations for shows, dining experiences etc. Toronto like most major, successful urban centers grows organically; it is a collection of neighborhoods.  A casino is a blight, not a participant, in any neighborhood.  A casino is a way to privatize the entertainment experience.  That will result in more dollars leaving the city than coming in and it is not what a large, culturally diverse urban center needs.  Smaller places without a vast amount of entertainment and cultural options can place a casino in the middle of its center and say Look, we have entertainment. Toronto does not need that. Toronto is rated in the top 10 cities in the world consistently.  This is because of many factors - livability, walkability, cleanliness, access to outdoor space, low crime etc.  A casino does not add to these things and is likely to damage all of them.

Even the most profitable casinos are profitable for the owners/operators and not for local businesses, residents or for casino workers. I have yet to see a gambler go exploring the city in which a casino is located. The best they do is to buy a few luxury items in the casino complex IF they win. I do believe that a casino will cost the City of Toronto more than we will benefit from it. If casinos were so great (like the lobbyists and the industry say), every city would want one. There are already several casinos and gambling options near Toronto including Niagara, CasinoRama, Woodbine - it would not be a unique or distinctive addition to the city and is unlikely to add to Toronto as a tourism destination. Casinos typically are very "cut off" from their surrounding with low lighting, few windows and other design features to keep patrons focussed on gambling and keeping them inside. This will not integrate with Toronto's vibrant streetscape and would be a waste of valuable land, particularly if a casino is located downtown and/or near Lake Ontario. Toronto's tourism, entertainment and service sectors are doing fairly well right now - I don't believe a casino would bring notable financial benefits to this sector though it would bring substantial financial costs in terms of dealing with problem gamblers, etc.

The examples of Windsor,  Niagara Falls and Detroit indicate that casinos do not bring either the revenue nor the benefits to their hosts the proponents suggest. As job creators & contributors to the city's GSP, casinos are less effective than local businesses or direct economic stimulation via public sector spending. In fact, casinos tend to hollow out the local neighbourhood, reducing foot traffic. Removing people from a streetscape, removes their dollars as this money is spent elsewhere and impulse spending - ie, I'm thirsty, maybe I'll stop at that coffee shop just up the street - is lost. The associated costs of servicing the casino in terms of city services will be born by the city and are likely to exceed the returns to the city from the casino, as demonstrated by Niagara Falls and Windsor who reportedly receive $3 million/year from casino operations in those cities.
